1956

May 8, 1912.

Dr. King Yin Kwan,

Imperial Medical College,

Tientain, China.

My dear Dr. Kwan:

Your letter of April 9th with enclosed drafts amounting

to $1000.24 has just been received.

The money which I am creating to

your boy's account a little more than covers his obligations, and leaves

a balance on hand of $14.88.

This I will hold until I hear further in

regard to the boy's plans, for only this morning Loe informed me that 
Sung sing intended to return to this country in the fall. If he is

not to return, kindly advise me and I will see that the account in que -
ton is returned to you at once.

I deeply regret to learn of the trials through which you have

recently been called upon to pass, for I can well understand that the

unsettled conditions in China must have been a source of constant anxiety

to all of you.

It is to be hoped, however, that the splendid results

which have been achieved will more then compensate you for the tribute -
tons and losses of recent months.

Please accept my deep sympathy for

the personal loss you have sustained in the death of your father.

I sincerely trust that you have not been unduly burdened by the

knowledge that Sung Sing had not fully closed his account høre. Only 
within a few days I have received both from hr. Tong and from Mr. Lee 
additional reaittances, so that the boys now with us have at present 
very comfortable balances on hand. I have hesitated to call the attend -
ton of their parents and guardians in China to the situation, knowing

full well how strenuous life and its demands upon you must have been

metadata.name: Phillips Academy
metadata.abstract: Letter acknowledging letter of with drafts of $1000.24 covering his son's obligations and leaving a balance of $14.88 which will be remitted if Sung Sing does not return to school in the fall. He also regrets the unsettled conditions in China and sends his sympathy on the death of Kwan's father. Stearns regrets that he had to send reminders to Dr. Kwan as well as Mr. Tong and Mr. Lee in view of the burdens of living in China. He advises Dr. Kwan to impress upon his son the importance of limiting his expenses.
